6/ Brown and Medoff (1918) gathered data by 2Ã¢â¬âdigit industry for 1929 and 1953 to use with data on unionization in these two years found in Lewis (1963, pp. 289Ã¢â¬â290) in an effort to capture productivity before and after unionization. They regressed the change in in (value added/labor) on the change in in (captial/labor) and the change in fraction unionized. With only 20 observations they could not estimate the union productivity effect with any precision. The estimated coefficient on the change in fractionÃ¢â¬âunionized variable ranged from negative to positive depending on the data used and the assumptions made.
